articles.headline: Why Stand in Line on Black Friday? The Psychology Explained
articles.snippet: Lines on Black Friday are different from lines at the supermarket, often causing emotional behavior and generating a carnival atmosphere.
articles.abstract: Lines on Black Friday are different from lines at the supermarket, often causing emotional behavior and generating a carnival atmosphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing in line is a pain. At the post office. At the box office. At a restaurant.

articles.headline: A Split From Trump Indicates That Flynn Is Moving to Cooperate With Mueller
articles.snippet: Lawyers for Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, are said to have terminated an information-sharing agreement with the president’s legal team.
articles.abstract: Lawyers for Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, are said to have terminated an information-sharing agreement with the president’s legal team.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, notified the president’s legal team in recent days that they could no longer discuss the special counsel’s investigation, according to four people involved in the case — an indication that Mr. Flynn is cooperating with prosecutors or negotiating a deal.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Matt Apuzzo and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Facebook Founder’s Favor Comes With Complications
articles.snippet: Wherever Mark Zuckerberg goes in Silicon Valley, he seems to generate a housing problem, including at an R.V. community where residents were evicted this month.
articles.abstract: Wherever Mark Zuckerberg goes in Silicon Valley, he seems to generate a housing problem, including at an R.V. community where residents were evicted this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST PALO ALTO, Calif. — Adrian Bonilla lived in a shared house in this Silicon Valley town with his wife and two grandchildren until earlier this year, when the rent for their bedroom jumped to $1,200 from $900 a month. Mr. Bonilla attributed that rise to Facebook, which is based nearby and was growing.

articles.headline: Nafta Talks Have High Stakes for Two Texas Bridge Owners
articles.snippet: Private crossings to Mexico are a rich franchise under the North American Free Trade Agreement, but discussions on reopening the accord have put that bonanza at risk.
articles.abstract: Private crossings to Mexico are a rich franchise under the North American Free Trade Agreement, but discussions on reopening the accord have put that bonanza at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex. — Caught quite literally in the middle of the international debate over the way the United States trades with its southern neighbor are two Texans named Sam.

articles.headline: Will a Corporate Tax Cut Lift Worker Pay? A Union Wants It in Writing
articles.snippet: The request, while unlikely to be heeded, highlights a critical question over who would benefit the most from the tax bill: shareholders or workers?
articles.abstract: The request, while unlikely to be heeded, highlights a critical question over who would benefit the most from the tax bill: shareholders or workers?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the heart of the Republican tax plan hurtling through Congress is an implicit promise that cutting corporate taxes will lift the middle class through higher wages and more jobs.

articles.headline: Why Putin’s Foes Deplore U.S. Fixation on Election Meddling
articles.snippet: “Enough already!” one critic of President Vladimir V. Putin said, worried that the accusations were helping the Kremlin polish the president’s image as a master strategist.
articles.abstract: “Enough already!” one critic of President Vladimir V. Putin said, worried that the accusations were helping the Kremlin polish the president’s image as a master strategist.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — For months, President Vladimir V. Putin has predictably denied accusations of Russian interference in last year’s American election, denouncing them as fake news fueled by Russophobic hysteria.

articles.headline: Does Race Matter in America’s Most Diverse ZIP Codes?
articles.snippet: Vallejo, Calif., is the rare city where no one ethnic group predominates. But stubborn disparities endure.
articles.abstract: Vallejo, Calif., is the rare city where no one ethnic group predominates. But stubborn disparities endure.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALLEJO, Calif. — Beyond the burgers and fries coming from the kitchen and the oldies blaring from the radio, the scene playing out daily at the Original Red Onion might appear unfamiliar to much of the country.

articles.headline: Why Tobacco Companies Are Paying to Tell You Smoking Kills
articles.snippet: Court-ordered ads, which will start appearing on Sunday, are “corrective statements” about the health risks and addictive nature of smoking.
articles.abstract: Court-ordered ads, which will start appearing on Sunday, are “corrective statements” about the health risks and addictive nature of smoking.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest tobacco companies in the United States will start running prime-time television commercials and full-page ads in national newspapers on Sunday — but the campaign is unlikely to spur enthusiasm for their products.

articles.headline: Militants Kill 305 at Sufi Mosque in Egypt’s Deadliest Terrorist Attack
articles.snippet: The assault, in an area racked by an Islamist insurgency, sent shock waves across the nation — not only for the death toll but also for the choice of target.
articles.abstract: The assault, in an area racked by an Islamist insurgency, sent shock waves across the nation — not only for the death toll but also for the choice of target.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Militants detonated a bomb inside a crowded mosque in the Sinai Peninsula on Friday and then sprayed gunfire on panicked worshipers as they fled, killing at least 305 people and wounding at least 128 others. Officials called it the deadliest terrorist attack in Egypt’s modern history.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Nour Youssef
